title: 107_hr3041
content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel America Now Act of 2001". Prior to September 11, 2001, the travel and tourism industry in the United States employed over 19 million people with a payroll of $171.5 billion. In 2000, the industry generated over $582 billion in expenditures and $99.6 billion in tax revenues. Additionally, it created a $14 billion trade surplus for the country. Post-9/11, efforts are being made to ensure safe and secure travel. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for revitalizing the US economy post-9/11. The public should be encouraged to travel for both personal and business reasons to support working people and stimulate economic growth. SEC. 25C. PERSONAL TRAVEL CREDIT is a new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, aimed at encouraging personal travel to support economic growth. The new section added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, SEC. 25C, allows individuals a tax credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint returns, covering expenses related to travel and lodging. The new section SEC. 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a tax credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The credit covers expenses related to travel and lodging, excluding meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. Qualifying personal trips must be within the United States, involve an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and have a destination at least 100 miles away from the taxpayer's residence. The new section SEC. 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The credit covers expenses related to travel and lodging at commercial facilities like hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules include denying the credit to dependents and requiring expenses to be substantiated. The new section SEC. 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002. The credit covers expenses related to travel and lodging at commercial facilities like hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. Special rules include denying the credit to dependents and requiring expenses to be substantiated by adequate records or evidence. No deduction is allowed for expenses where a credit is claimed. SEC. 4 of the Act temporarily increases the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses to 100 percent for expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment date. SEC. 5. NET OPERATING LOSS CARRYBACK FOR TRAVEL AND TOURISM INDUSTRY. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back as net operating losses for five preceding taxable years. The amendment allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back as net operating losses for five preceding taxable years. Section 172 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include rules relating to travel and tourism industry losses, defining terms and businesses related to the industry. The tourism business includes activities related to travel such as transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and entertainment facilities. Losses in the travel and tourism industry can be carried back as net operating losses for five preceding taxable years. The tax code allows for travel or tourism losses to be treated similarly to specified liability losses. Taxpayers can elect a 5-year carryback period for losses, with the option to disregard certain provisions. Related taxpayers can also make elections under regulations set by the Secretary. The tax code allows for travel or tourism losses to be credited against taxable income earned during a 5-year carryback period by related taxpayers within a controlled group of corporations. These amendments apply to taxable years ending before, on, or after the date of enactment of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in article I, section 8 of the US Constitution.
